definition: to shift one's eyes/(fig.) to shift one's attention/to divert attention
see 轉文|转文[zhuai3 wen2]
to revolve/to turn/to circle about/to walk about/classifier for revolutions (per minute etc): revs, rpm/classifier for repeated actions
to turn/to change direction/to transfer/to forward (mail)
to move/to shift/to change/to alter/to remove
to look at/to regard/to inspect
old variant of 視|视[shi4]
variant of 視|视[shi4]/variant of 示[shi4]
thread/string/wire/line/CL:條|条[tiao2],股[gu3],根[gen1]/(after a number) tier (unofficial ranking of a Chinese city)
variant of 線|线[xian4]

sentences.english: Looking away from people or yawning will, in most cases, make me appear to be uninterested .
sentences.chinese: 转移视线或不停地打哈欠大多说明这个人不感兴趣。

sentences.english: He averts his eyes from the terrible sight.
sentences.chinese: 他转移视线不看那可怕的景象。

sentences.english: Casino at's Western media for you, diverting attention.
sentences.chinese: 这就是西方的媒体，在转移视线。

sentences.english: After the demonstration, as Israel accused Syria to divert attention.
sentences.chinese: 示威发生后，以色列指责叙利亚以此转移视线。

sentences.english: From time to time, she would take her eyes' off the book and reach up to touch his wrinkled cheek.
sentences.chinese: 她时不时的从书上转移视线抬起头来碰到他褶皱的脸。

sentences.english: That's Western media for you, diverting attention.
sentences.chinese: 这就是西方的媒体，在转移视线。

sentences.english: Honest people sometimes avert their gaze when they are telling the truth.
sentences.chinese: 诚实的人有时候会在说真话的时候转移视线。

sentences.english: The political instability that results from depression makes war an attractive option to divert attention.
sentences.chinese: 由萧条导致的政治上的不稳定将引发战争以转移视线。

definition: trying to hide it makes it more conspicuous (idiom); A cover up only makes matters worse.
to use the current topic to put over one's own ideas/to use sth as a pretext to make a fuss
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
bad habit (e.g. nose-picking)/petty maneuver/dirty trick/gamesmanship
to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
to cover up/to conceal/to mask/to gloss over
to have an ulterior motive (idiom)
to exculpate/to absolve/to exonerate
to say a matter has no relationship with the individual referred to, to emphasise one is innocent or in the clear
deliberately/on purpose
lit. the more you touch things up, the darker they get/fig. to only make matters worse
lit. 300 silver taels not hidden here (idiom); fig. to reveal what one intends to hide
pinyin: ci3 di4 wu2 yin2 san1 bai3 liang3

definition: lit. the voice of the guest overwhelms that of the host (idiom)/fig. a minor player upstages the main attraction/minor details obscure the main point/the sauce is better than the fish
to seduce/to lead into sex
to overreach oneself/to try to be clever and end up with egg on one's face
to confess without being pressed/to make a confession without duress
